required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Assessment of the Relative Increase in Bioavailability of (Non-) Nutrients From a Mixed Salad by Adding Fat Containing Dressing
clinical_study.official_title: Assessment of the Relative Increase in Bioavailability of (Non-) Nutrients From a Mixed Salad by Adding Fat Containing Dressing

brief_summary.textblock: The hypothesis will be tested that fat can also increase absorption of (non)-nutrients from a salad. Therefore we designed the current study to show an increase in relative absorption (bioavailability) of (non-) nutrients from a mixed salad by adding fat containing dressing.

primary_outcome.measure: Area under the curve (AUC in nmol/l*h) of (non) nutrients
primary_outcome.description: Area under the curve (AUC in nmol/l*h) of (non) nutrients. The AUCs are constructed from (non-) nutrient levels measured in plasma chylomicrons at the selected time-points. The size of the areas under the curves will be compared between the test and control dressing.

arm_group.description: Test product: Salad with high dosage fat
Control product: Salad with low dosage fat

intervention.intervention_name: Test product: Salad with a high dosage fat
Control product: Salad with low dosage fat

criteria.textblock:
Main inclusion Criteria:
- Body mass index (BMI) ≥ 18.5 and ≤ 30.0 kg/m2.
- Apparently healthy: no medical conditions, no use of prescribed or over the counter drugs, which might affect study measurements (as judged by study physician)
- Haemoglobin within normal reference range as judged by the study physician.
- Total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, HDL cholesterol and fasting triglycerides within the normal reference range, as judged by the study physician.
Main exclusion Criteria:
- Reported use of any medically- or self-prescribed diet at the moment of screening, or the intention to use any kind of diet in the period between screening and the end of the study.
- Reported weight loss or gain ≥ 10 % of bodyweight during a period of six months before screening.
- A known food allergy or intolerance.
- A dislike to the foods supplied during the study.
- Use of vitamins or supplements enriched with carotenoid and/or vitamin A and/of vitamin K.
- Known hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism.

overall_official.last_name: Dr. Raul C. Maranhão, M.D, Ph.D.
overall_official.affiliation: Head Professor of Clinical Biochemistry, Faculty of Pharmaceutical Sciences Director, Lipid Metabolism Laboratory
